title: 108_hr751
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." is a condensed summary of the section's title, findings, and purposes. The Act may be cited as the "Responsible Off-Road Vehicle Enforcement and Response Act." Congress finds that public lands provide opportunities for recreational activities, vehicle use should be permitted but regulated to prevent damage and violations of regulations should be addressed. The Act, known as the "Responsible Off-Road Vehicle Enforcement and Response Act," aims to regulate vehicle use on public lands to prevent damage. It proposes appropriate fines for violations of regulations and the reimbursement of restoration costs to the United States. To use funds from fines for land restoration, public awareness, and enforcement of regulations on vehicle use in public lands. SEC. 2. PUBLIC LANDS. The amendment allows the Secretary to impose fines up to $10,000 for damages to public lands from violations of vehicle use regulations, with fines used for improvement work. The amendment allows fines imposed for violations of vehicle use regulations to be used for administrative expenses, improvement work on public lands, and increasing public awareness of regulations. The amendment allows fines for violations of vehicle use regulations to be used for administrative expenses, public land improvement, and public awareness of regulations. Additionally, Section 3 pertains to national forest lands. The amendment allows the Secretary of Agriculture to impose fines up to $10,000 for vehicle violations on Forest Service lands, with the fine amount based on the cost of necessary improvements or damages. Violations not resulting in death are considered Class B misdemeanors. The amendment allows fines up to $10,000 for vehicle violations on Forest Service lands, based on necessary improvements or damages. Violations not resulting in death are considered Class B misdemeanors. Amendments to Section 7 of the Act of June 20, 1958 include provisions for administrative, legal, and related expenses incurred in connection with claims. Any excess funds received will be used for enforcement and public awareness of regulations on such lands.
